Comment: **TL;DR**: American higher education, long the world's envy, faces an existential crisis in 2025. A vengeful presidential administration targets universities, causing chaos—students, scholars, and programs suffer while elites scramble to protect endowments. Comment: Education is a privilege. Not a guaranteed right. It hasn’t even been mandatory for that long. The first education act was in 1852 in Massachusetts and it wasn’t until 1918 that all states finally had educational state law.  Here we are. Turns out educating the masses leads to free thinking and that conflicts with the current administrations ability to control the general public. We stand on the threshold of a new dark age. Historically when the church held the power of education they did not teach the masses how to read and write, they taught them only to fear God and obey their masters or rulers and they would all go to heaven . Cathedrals of Europe were adorned with paintings and tapestries of the atrocities of hell. You could ask the priest if you wanted to know more. An uneducated population is easier to control.

Comment: It’s focused on higher education. College is not for everyone. It used to be that young adults were taught a skill in highschool. In the 1990s schools started closing down the sheet metal , auto mechanic , wood working, farming  programs to name a few.  This led to a mass amount of unprepared people being pushed into furthering education in areas that simply do not have the demand. Side effect was the whole student loan movement because how else were they all going to keep up with the narrative?  I don’t agree with how they are dismantling the education system, I’m quite worried about personal freedoms and the sudden religious movement which spanks of ignorance . Let us hope that they bring back the programs that prepared people to make a living in this world.  There are enough college graduates not even working in their field of study. That system is already broken.
Author: FireWaterSquaw

Comment: >It’s focused on higher education. College is not for everyone.  Of course, higher education is focused on higher education.  Conversely, trade schools are focused on trade schools.  People who do not want to go to college have other options.   > It used to be that young adults were taught a skill in highschool.  In the 1990s schools started closing down the sheet metal , auto mechanic , wood working, farming programs to name a few. This led to a mass amount of unprepared people being pushed into furthering education in areas that simply do not have the demand. Side effect was the whole student loan movement because how else were they all going to keep up with the narrative?  That narrative is ludicrous.   Never in American history have young adults been educated in high school.  After all, it is a fact that teenagers are not the same thing as young adults.  Furthermore, industries that previously required skills for sheet metal and woodworking were automated.  It is illogical to spend education funds on skills that are no longer required by their industries.  There are still lots of high schools across the country that teach other skills like auto mechanics, nursing assistant, information technology, etc.  The student debt crisis is the direct result of another crappy policy from Republicans.  [What Caused the $1.6 Trillion Student Debt Crisis? | BestColleges](https://www.bestcolleges.com/news/analysis/what-caused-the-student-debt-crisis/)  > I don’t agree with how they are dismantling the education system, I’m quite worried about personal freedoms and the sudden religious movement which spanks of ignorance . Let us hope that they bring back the programs that prepared people to make a living in this world. There are enough college graduates not even working in their field of study. That system is already broken.  There are lots of causes of ignorance.  Aside from religious reasons, there is personal freedoms as you stated.  Personal freedoms include contriving narratives that are based on obviously absurd premises.  No high school is bringing back woodworking to teach teenagers as a job skill because this is not the 1800s where people can make a scratch living in that industry by making furniture by hand which cannot fulfill in supply and demand in our modern era.  We can fix systems.  The Republicans clearly have no interest in fixing the student debt crisis they wrought in our nation.
Author: ResidentKelpien
